column6: Description
Residents can apply to receive a free energy consultation with a volunteer 'Energy Hero' (volunteer community members).
column15: The 'Energy Hero' can cover a range of energy saving initiatives within the home, such as insulation and draught-proofing, energy efficient heating & cooling, efficient hot water, solar and batteries. However, they will not give specific technical advice or make recommendations for businesses.

column6: Residents can borrow Home Energy Kits from the library.

Residents can have free access to:
- Energy advice available over-the-phone, email and through the Australian Energy Foundation website. Energy advisors provide personalised advice about the products most suitable for your needs within your budget.
- Obligation-free quotes from trusted and vetted suppliers, for hot water heat pumps, reverse cycle air-conditioners, solar panels and solar batteries.
- Assistance with applying for available rebates.
column13: Mornington Peninsula Shire Council; Australian Energy Foundation

column4: Energy and Water Efficiency Home Audit Kit
column6: Kits available for borrowing from library.
After using the Energy and Water Efficiency Home Audit Kit and identifying air leaks in the home, residents can apply for a rebate of up to $200 to draught proof the home.
column10:
- Only available for properties located in the City of Casey (proof of residence required). 
- Only one application per household will be accepted for an indefinite period. 
- Applications can be submitted for up to a maximum of $200 AUD. If the full $200 is not claimed, additional applications cannot be made.   
- Full proof of purchase is required detailing the applicant's first and last name, company name (if applicable), purchase date and the name and cost of each item purchased. Partial copies will not be accepted. 
- Applicants must have borrowed and used a City of Casey Energy and Water Efficiency Home Audit Kit (proof of use required).  
- Receipts for draught-proofing items must be dated from the past six (6) months from date of submission. 
- Products must be installed by the resident or an un-paid helper. The rebate cannot be used to pay a trades person or require a technical trade to install including plumber, electrician, builder, insulation installer or glazier.   
- Applications are to be submitted online via https://rebately.co/ only.
column15:
Rebates can be submitted for the following types of products: 
- door and window draught stoppers 
- chimney draught stoppers 
- hot water system insulators and lagging (including the purchase of one roll of electrical tape) 
- block out roller blinds 
- pelmets 
- honeycomb blinds 
- thermal blinds 
- window insulation 
- reflective window film 
- garage door weather seals 
- gap fillers 
- sealants.

column6: The handbook makes recommendations regarding ways in which residents can increase their home's energy efficiency through making physical and structural changes to their homes.

Cardinia Shire Council is partnering with Solar Savers to offer access to quality solar PV systems, batteries and energy efficient products (heat pump hot water systems and heating and cooling split systems) for homes and businesses across the shire.

Through Solar Savers, residents can access eligible rebates and loans.
column14: Since 2018, Solar Savers has supported the installation of over 550 solar PV systems in Victoria.

column6:
The Council has contracted an accredited Scorecard assessor to provide in home energy assessments for a small number of Kingston’s senior residents (forty households in total).

The aim of the Program is to help senior residents:
- Reduce energy use and save money by better understanding how to make their homes more energy efficient, 
- Get tailored advice on a range of potential home upgrades to achieve better energy efficiency and thermal comfort
- Reduce energy use and greenhouse gas emissions
column10:
- Kingston Resident (either home owner or renter); and
- Agree to the Terms and Conditions of Kingston’s in home energy assessments (Scorecard) program
column15:
Participants will receive a personalised in-home energy assessment, Scorecard Certificate, and tailored advice at no cost to the participant.
 
Your Scorecard assessor will provide the participant with advice on how to reduce energy costs in their home.

column6: Kingston Libraries now have induction cook tops available to borrow via Kingston’s library catalogue. These provide a useful demonstration of the power and convenience of induction cooking compared to gas, helping residents “trial” transitioning to a fully electric home.
Residents can book a 10-minute appointment with one of the Council's ESD officers

Kits available for borrowing from library.

Each kit contains:
- A Power-Mate™ Lite Energy Monitor that measures how much electrical power is being used by an appliance  
- An Energy Saving Thermometer to check whether the temperature of your rooms, fridge and freezer are set to the most energy efficient ranges
- A Non-contact Thermometer measuring the temperature of an object or surface using an infrared sensor
- A Water Flow Measuring Cup to calculate flow rate and help save water
column15: A separate FLIR Thermal Imaging Camera is also available for borrowing to help identify less obvious areas where the home may be leaking heat.

column6: Residents can borrow an induction cooktop from Yarra Libraries' new Library of Things to try out induction cooking at home.

The Council has partnered with Government-accredited Scorecard assessors, Ephe, to offer the community quality home energy assessments at an affordable cost.

Each Boroondara household is eligible for one Council discounted assessment. The Assessment is valued at $452. After state government discounts and Council subsidies have been applied, the price is $88 for eligible concession card holders, and $176 for non eligible concession card holders.
column14: The program is still in its trial stage, but the Council has indicated that the program has been successful and will continue through to 2025.
column15:
Boroondara residents can access a Scorecard assessment with a further 50% discount off the already subsidised Victorian Energy Upgrade program (VEU) price. 

Boroondara residents who hold one of the below concession cards, can access an assessment for 75% off the VEU subsidised price: Health Care Card; Pensioner Concession Card; Veterans’ Affairs Gold Card.

Ephe will apply the Victorian Energy Upgrade program subsidy and the Council discount at the time of booking. If you hold an eligible concession card, you will need to provide proof when booking.

Each household is eligible for one Council discounted assessment.

column6: Residents can book a meter (Power-Mate Lite kit) at one of the Council's libraries and reserve a kit online.

The Solar Savers program was launched in Boroondara on 1 January 2022 offering Boroondara residents and businesses access to good value Solar PV systems.

This program helps residents get:

The Council has partnered with home energy experts Ephe to offer residents a discount on a home energy assessment with 75% off for concession holders and 50% off for all other residents.
Cost: $88 concession, $176 non concession.

The expert wil give a personalised report on next steps.

Assessment items include:
- gaps and draughts
- insulation in your roof cavity, under floor and walls
- heating and cooling systems
- window treatments
- external shading options.

column4:
Better Score grant

Better Score Energy Efficiency Upgrade Program
column6:
Each household is eligible for a fully subsidised scorecard assessment worth $500 and a grant of up to $1000 covering up to 60% of the total expense.

Maximum individual funding available is $1,500, including the $500 cost of the 2 scorecard assessments and the tailored energy report.
column10:
Eligible for a reimbursement grant if:
- you are a Banyule resident
- the property you are getting upgraded has a value of less than $3 million
- your combined household taxable income does not exceed $210,000 per year (based on your Australian Tax Office notice of assessment)
- you or your household have not previously received a Better Score grant
- you own and live in the property being upgraded or, if rented, have the written approval from the landlord to carry out the upgrade(s)
- you agree to implement at least 1 upgrade identified in your scorecard assessment(Show info)
- you engage licensed contractors to complete the upgrade(s)
- you agree to have a variation assessment(Show info) done after the upgrade(s) are complete
- you agree to the program terms and conditions

Council staff not eligible.
column11:
1 July 2024: applications open @ 9am

19 July 2024: applications close @ 5pm

7 May 2025: grant acquittal is due by 5pm
column15: A total of $75,000 was allocated for the financial year 2024/2025

The Hume Household Solar Rollout program was a partnership between Hume City Council and the Yarra Energy Foundation (YEF), with an accredited solar provider, Green Home Green Planet, who offered solar panel installations.
column13: Hume City Council; Yarra Energy Foundation; Green Home Green Plant
column14:
One megawatt (1,000 kW) of solar installed across households in Hume City through the program, reducing greenhouse gas emissions by approximately 1,050 tonnes (CO2-e) per year - equivalent to removing around 205 average Australian cars off the road each year. 

https://www.hume.vic.gov.au/Residents/Latest-News/News-and-Media-Releases/2023/Hume-Solar-Rollout-passes-1MW-mark

column6:
This program builds upon the previous Hume Solar Rollout program.

A range of electric appliances and other energy-efficient upgrades are available to residential property owners, including: reverse cycle heating and cooling systems (split systems), electric heat pump hot water systems, rooftop solar, electric induction cooktops, insulation and draught proofing.

Council is also offering rebates, valued between $400 and $1000, to eligible concession card holders who take advantage of the program. These rebates are in addition to government discounts, rebates and no-interest loans.

The program will be delivered in partnership with Yarra Energy Foundation (YEF) and vetted suppliers, EnviroGroup and Enviroflex.

The Council supports the Solar Savers Program.
column10:
Local homeowners are eligible for the program if:
- They live in Maribyrnong City Council
- They own the property
- They do not already have solar panels installed on the home.

Local renters may be eligible for the program if;
- They live in Maribyrnong City Council
- They do not already have solar panels on the property
- The household has an annual income below $180,000 .

column6:
The program offers residents a tailored assessment of appliances in their home, an electrification plan complete with a quote for the purchase and installation of carefully vetted products and support to access all available government rebates.

Residents can access three assessment options with scaled pricing:

Phone call (10 mins) – For general questions about home electrification and the service itself (FREE)
Video call (30 mins) – Generally, to discuss 2 items (e.g., hot water and cooktop) (Cost: $79)
Home visit (45 mins) – Generally, to discuss 3 or more items (Cost: 199)
column7:
Apartments

This program is open to owner occupiers and residential landlords of properties in the Moonee Valley municipality only.
column15:
This project is part of Let’s Go Zero – Moonee Valley, a community carbon emissions reduction program funded through Council’s Climate Reserve.

There are also a limited number of financial subsidies to support residents on a low income to install an induction cooktop. These will be allocated to eligible residents on a first come first served basis until the allocation is exhausted. To be eligible, residents must have a Health Care Card, Veterans Card, Pensioners Card or be Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander.

column4: Home Environment Kit & Thermal Imaging Camera
column6:
The Home Environment Kit contains the following equipment to help residents find ways of saving energy and water around their home:
- Energy smart thermometer - measures hot water temperature, room temperature, and fridge and freezer temperatures. You may have things hotter or colder than they need to be
- Infra-red thermometer - measures surface temperatures such as walls and windows. You may be losing or gaining heat which can be fixed with insulation or shade
- Energy monitor - measures energy consumption of your appliances to see which ones need to be used sparingly, and where standby power is being drawn needlessly
- Light meter - to help apply the ideal light conditions in your home and using energy wisely
- Water flow measure cup - to assess how much water your shower and taps use and to see whether you should reduce the flow rates.

Residents can also borrow thermal imaging cameras to identify energy inefficiencies in your home, such as poorly insulated areas.

The Western Alliance for Greenhouse Action group, including Brimbank Council, has come together to bring a series of expert online events from the sustainability and energy experts at Renew, who provide independent advice.
column13: Brimbank Council + other councils in the Western Alliance for Greenhouse Alliance

column4: Z-NET Home Energy Assessments and Energy Savvy Upgrades Program
column6:
The program provided residents support to improve building comfort and running costs by tackling energy efficiency, providing energy audits and some funding for efficiency upgrades. 

The program was led by Transition Creswick and assisted to access a free assessment valued at $330 dollars, and a subsidy from the State Government of up to $880 dollars to complete energy efficiency upgrades to make each home more comfortable and affordable to run.
column15: This program reached its household energy assessment and efficiency upgrades targets in June 2022 and is now closed to new applications.

column6: This is a Council-led project where Council purchases solar systems upfront for eligible pensioners and low-income households within the Shire. This cost is then recouped using a ‘Special Rates Charge’ through an interest-free loan on the property. Households are only encouraged to proceed when modelling suggests that annual energy savings will be $100 greater than the loan repayments.
column10: Unclear (not sure if it is only for pensioners and low-income households within the LGA)

column6: The Hepburn Solar Bulk-Buy is a community initiative – supported by Council, Hepburn Wind and Z-NET Hepburn Shire – to make it easier for households and businesses to go solar and add battery storage, contributing to the Shire’s zero-net emissions target for 2030.
column13: Hepburn Shire Council; Hepburn Wind; Z-NET Hepburn Shire

column6:
Residents are being invited to electrify their homes, save on power bills and transition to a renewable energy future through the Electric Homes Program.

The program, which is being delivered by Geelong Sustainability through a $50,000 Climate Change Partnerships grant, will connect residents with trusted local installers of solar, solar batteries, heating and cooling options, and hot water heat pumps to help upgrade households.
This is a demonstration site which showcases products and technologies including solar, energy storage, ventilation, lighting, insulation, hot water, heating and cooling.

The Electric Homes Program has a focus on promoting energy-efficient solutions, including solar panels, batteries, and other home efficiency improvements.

The program will provide participating homes with:
- A comprehensive energy audit to identify opportunities for energy savings.
- A variety of products and services including solar, battery storage, heating and cooling split systems, hot water heat pumps, electric vehicle chargers, induction cooktop installations, home insulation and draught proofing.
- Unique services and pricing on certain products as part of the program by trusted businesses and service providers,
- Information sessions to help educate residents about the benefits of energy-efficient home upgrades.
column13: Geelong, Borough of Queenscliffe, Surf Coast, Golden Plains and Colac Otway Shire Councils

column6:
The Council supports the Electric Homes Program.

It is a regional program supported by Geelong, Borough of Queenscliffe, Surf Coast, Golden Plains and Colac Otway Shire Councils along with a large number of local community sustainability groups including Southern Otway Sustainable, the Colac Otway Sustainability Group and the Birregurra Community Group.

column6:
The program, in partnership with Berrybank Windfarm operator Global Power Generation, offers energy upgrades for people who meet eligibility criteria and attend one of three online information sessions.

Upgrades included either draught-proofing, ceiling or underfloor insulation, new appliances, window coverings or external blinds.

EEP1 was a pilot program.
column14:
10 home-owners received new appliances and efficiency upgrades.

“Some homes initially had a star rating of just one, two or four out of nine” said Geelong Sustainability Project Coordinator Dan Cowdell.

“Following upgrades we were able to increase that star rating by an average of 0.6 stars while two homes were able to increase it by two stars which is a phenomenal result.”
